reviewText: **** - Great, one of the best episodes of the series***1/2 - Very good*** - Good**1/2 - Fair** or below - Not good or badTales From The Crypt: The Complete Fourth Season (1992)1.) None But The Lonely Heart *** 6/27/92  Starring Treat Williams, Frances Sternhagen, Henry Gibson, Sugar Ray Leonard, Tom Hanks, Written by Donald Longtooth, Directed by Tom HanksThey're wed, than dead. A young man kills the wealthy biddies he marries. But some vows must be kept.2.) This'll Kill Ya *1/2 6/27/92  Starring Dylan McDermot, Sonia Braga and Cleavon Little, Written by Gilbert Adler and A L Katz, Directed by Robert LongoA presciption for doom: Coworkers at a drug research firm give a cruel boss a dose of his own medicine.3.) On A Deadman's Chest **** 6/27/92  Starring Tia Carerre, Paul Hipp, Sherrie Rose, Gregg Allman, Yul Vasquez, Written by Larry Wilson, Directed by William FriedkenImagine a tattoo that seems to have a life of its own. Or, instead of imagining, watch this!4.) Seance *** 7/4/92  Starring Cathy Moriarty, Ben Cross and John Vernon, Written by Harry Anderson, Directed by Gary FlederHoney, is that you? Filmflammers aim to bilk millions from a widow by pulling off a spootacular seance.5.) Beauty Rest **1/2 7/11/92  Starring Mimi Rogers, Kathy Ireland, Jennifer Rubin and Buck Henry; Written by Donald Longtooth, Directed by Stephen HopkinsShe'd kill for the part...twice. But it's not acting talent that counts for this role. It's inner beauty!6.) What's Cookin' **** 7/22/92  Starring Christopher Reeve, Bess Armstrong, Judd Nelson, Art LeFleur and Meat Loaf, Written by A L Katz and Gilbert Adler, Directed by Gilbert AdlerBusiness is great at the all-squid diner now that meat is on the menu. One question: Where's the meat come from?7.) The New Arrival **** 7/25/92  Starring David Warner, Twiggy Lawson, Joan Severance, Zelda Rubinstein and Robert Patrick, Written by Ron Finley, Directed by Peter MedakA tale of smotherly love. A talk-show shrink makes a house call to meet a listener and her unusual child.8.) Showdown *** 8/1/92  Starring David Morse and Neil Gray Ciuntoli, Written by Frank Darabont, Directed by Richard DonnerNow that's a real ghost town. A gunslinger arrives in a dusty nowhere populated by his victims.9.) King Of The Road **1/2 Starring Raymond J. Barry, Brad Pitt and Michelle Bronson, Written by J. Randal Johnson, Directed by Tom HollandNothing's fiercer than the human race! A drag racer goads a cop into competing by kidnapping the man's daughter.10.) Maniac At Large **** 8/19/92  Starring Blythe Danner, Salome Jens, Christopher Williams III and Adam Ant, Written by Mae Woods, Directed by John FrankenheimerSeven people have been slain. Who will be next? A mousey librarian frets over reports of a serial killer.11.) Split Personality **** 8/26/92  Starring Joe Pesci, Kristen Amber Citron, Jacqueline Alexandra Citron and Burt Young, Written by Fred Dekker, Directed by Joel SilverTwo gorgeous twins. Two lookalike brothers. Two happy marriages. One killer twist!12.) Strung Along ***1/2 9/2/92  Starring Donald O'Conner, Patricia Charbonneau and Zach Gillian, Written by Yale Udoff and Kevin Yagher, Directed by Kevin YagherA tale of murder...with strings attached. An aging puppeteer suspects his much younger wife has a lover.13.) Werewolf Concerto **1/2 9/9/92  Starring Timmothy Dalton, Beverly D'Angelo, Reginald VelJohnson, Lela Rochon, Dennis Farina, Charles Fleisher and Wolfgang Puck, Written by Scott Nimerfro, Directed by Steve PerryYou'll howl! A werewolf stalks the grounds of a resort hotel. But he's not the only creature on the prowl.14.) Curiosity Killed *** 9/16/92  Starring Margot Kidder, Kevin McCarthy, J.A. Preston and Madge Sinclair, Written by Stanley Ralph Ross, Directed by Elliot SilversteinCome on, one sip won't kill you! Senior citizens try to convince another oldster to drink a youth potion.Special Features:- Commentary on "What's Cookin'?" by the Crypt Keeper, writer Alan Katz & series choricler Digby Diehl- Stars of Season 4 montage hosted by the Crypt Keeper
summary: Another great season of HBO's "Tales From The Crypt"....

reviewText: And again - a chance to see great directors and great actors doing their job in a short format. Maybe I'm wrong but I recon "Tales From the Crypt" is the unique TV-show that gathered so many talented people in one place. This show always has been an analogue of some All-Star Game to me. Not for real, but soo spectacular!NONE BUT THE LONELY HEART - dir. Tom Hanks; starring: Tom Hanks, Frances Sternhagen, Sugar Ray Leonard.THIS'LL KILL YA - dir. Robert Longo; starring: Sonia Braga, Dylan McDermott.ON A DEADMAN'S CHEST - dir. William Friedkin; starring: Tia Carrere,  Paul Hipp,  Steve Jones.SEANCE - dir. Gary Fleder; starring: Ben Cross, Ellen Crawford, Cathy Moriarty.BEAUTY REST - dir. Stephen Hopkins; starring: Jennifer Rubin, Mimi Rogers, Anders Hove.WHAT'S COOKIN' - dir. Gilbert Adler; starring: Christopher Reeve, Meat Loaf.THE NEW ARRIVAL - dir. Peter Medak; starring: Joan Severance, David Warner, Robert Patrick.SHOWDOWN - dir. Richard Donner (written by Frank Darabont); starring: David Morse, Roderick Cook, Thomas F. Duffy.KING OF THE ROAD - dir. Tom Holland; starring: Brad Pitt, Raymond J. Barry, Michelle Bronson.MANIAC AT LARGE - dir. John Frankenheimer; starring: Obba Babatunde, Clarence Williams III.SPLIT PERSONALITY - dir. Joel Silver; starring: Joe Pesci, Troy Evans.STRUNG ALONG - dir. Kevin Yagher; starring: Zach Galligan, Patricia Charbonneau.WEREWOLF CONCERTO - dir. Steve Perry; starring: Timothy Dalton, Beverly D'Angelo, Dennis Farina.CURIOSITY KILLED - dir. Elliot Silverstein; starring: Kevin McCarthy,  Madge Sinclair.

reviewText: When season 4 rolled around Tales From The Crypt was a sensation. It's easy to see why. It was one of the best horror anthology shows ever created! And season 4 showed why the show was as great as it was.The episodesNone But The Lonely Heart - The season starts off in a solid way. It's not the best of the set. But it's overall a truly solid episode. Treat Williams is terrific and the end is SO Tales From the Crypt. Look out for Tom Hanks who also directed it! 3 out of 4This'll Kill Ya - Honestly one of the weaker episodes but even the weak episodes of this show are a must see. It's gets a bit dull at times and the final twist is predictable. Also this is not really horror. Not much to say but an okay watch. 2 out of 4On A Deadman's Chest - The most gruesome episode of the set. And also one of the very best. It involves an evil tatoo and a even more evil rock star. The finale is really gory! An overall brilliant episode directed by William Friedkin (The Exorcist) 4 out of 4Seance - Pretty weak overall when comparing it to the other episodes BUT it is still solid and watchable and the end is gory. Good but not very memorable overall. 2.5 out of 4Beauty Rest - One of my favorites of the set! If you liked Top Billing then you will love this one. One of the most memorable final scenes of the set by far. 4 out of 4What's Cooking - One of Tales most famous episodes. Easy to see why... it's terrific! Christopher Reeve and Judd Nelson are spot on and it has some of the most disturbing scenes of the fourth season.  One of the best of the season. A classic. 4 out of 4The New Arrival - The classics keep on coming with the creepiest episode of the season. David Warner stars but it is Zelda Rubenstein of Poltergeist fame who steals the show. Even model Twiggy pops up! Keeps you guessing till the very end and keeps you in suspense. 4 out of 4Showdown - Sadly season 4 comes with one of the worst episodes of the series. Showdown is really slow and boring Two Fisted Tale. Meh not much to say and there is nothing interesting here. Some ghosts. A missfire. 1.5 out of 4King Of The Road - Honestly this episode standouts cause it stars a young Brad Pitt. But on a whole it's not that great. An okay thriller. Not at all horror but it is also a Two Fisted Tale. Entertaining enough. 2.5 out of 4Maniac At Large - Okay we are back! One of my favorites of the set easily. A librarian thinks a killer is after her and the suspense unfolds. Creepy, well acted and a good solid twist! Watch out for Adam Ant. 4 out of 4Split Personality - Not my favorite of the set but this one works because of Joe Pesci. His performance keeps you watching. The final scene is memorable as well. Good episode overall. 3 out of 4Strung Along - A great episodes with a couple of good twists. Not much else to say but it IS great oh and Zach Galligan from the Gremlins films is in it. 3.5 out of 4Werewolf Concerto - One of the weaker episodes but it has an All Star cast. Timothy Dalton, Dennnis Farina.... on and on. I thought it lacked a little but most fans love it so you will probably too. 2.5 out of 4Curiosity Killed - Weird episode starring Margot Kidder. But in this case weird is good. Give it a chance it is better then it sounds honestly and the end is gruesome. A solid season finisher. 3 out of 4
summary: Tales From The Crypt at it's most popular

reviewText: I recently purchased most of the Tales from the Crypt DVDs and really enjoyed them.My issue here was that only Seasons 1,2,3,6 and 7 had English subtitles/captions.Season 4 and 5 say CC on the back of the packets, but do not have English captions or subtitles. I had to send them back. This was rather disappointing because I love Tales from the Crypt and would have loved to own the whole collection.I also recall another reviewer mentioning on here that not all these DVDs have the French subtitles either.I think it is great that HBO and Warner have put subtitles on most of these seasons, but I would love to see them put the full set of captions on ALL the seasons, so I could add them to my collection.Hopefully Season 4 and 5 will be produced on Blu-Ray with English subtitles.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A lot of memories with this season, this was the season when I started watching this series all of those years ago. The episodes haven't aged one bit and are still as interesting as they were way back then. More and more stars started to show up by this season. Big names like Tom Hanks, Brad Pitt and Timothy Dalton appear in a few of the episodes. This season isn't about the gore and the dead coming back for revenge, this season mainly focused on the twist endings and murder plots more than the undead, not saying that there isn't any here because there is.Once again, the special features are disappointing and the box is the same as season three. Butt all of that is forgivable with such great episodes that are in this season. If you are a fan of this series and have been getting all of the seasons released so far, this is another to add to your collection so far. While not all episodes are grade A stuff, most of them are. Another must have for fans and new comers alike!
summary: The Extras Are Lacking But The Episodes Are Still Great

reviewText: The Crypt Keeper is back for a great fourth season filled with classics. The show never seems to age as all the shorts are just as entertaining as they were 20 years ago. Wow can't believe it's been 20 years already. This is another must have season for any fan, and here are some of my favorites from season four:What's Cooking: A couple's failing restaurant gets a huge boost when a drifter gives them a steak recipe to die for. (My favorite from season 4)Strung Along: A game of deception ensues when a golden age puppeteer with a very young wife is given a chance to revive his act for a tribute show and takes on a new as his new assistant.On a Deadman's Chest: A disruptive rocker who despises his bandmate's new wife, receives a tattoo that looks exactly like her, so now not only does the woman he hate get under his skin but is now on it as well.Beauty rest: An aging down-on-her-luck model resorts to murder to get ahead and poses as her roommate to garner a beauty pageant spot that she's guaranteed to win.The New Arrival: To boost his troubled ratings, An arrogant radio child psychologist decides to do a series of shows from the home of a mother with the ultimate problem child.Maniac at Large: A shy library clerk is obsessed with a serial killer fearing that she will be the next victim.Split Personality: A slimy con man plans to marry some reclusive twins to inherit their fortune by creating a "twin" himself.

reviewText: By the Fourth Season, Tales From The Crypt was cranking out classic after classic. It was a very enjoyable time to be a Cryptfan, as well as a fan of HBO, with all of the great original programming such as Tales... and The Larry Sanders Show, as well as the great boxing action with the arrival of Roy Jones Jr. and what that meant for HBO Sports in the 90s. The point is that HBO was the best thing around and I have nothing but good memories of the time. Back then, when Tales From The Crypt came on you knew you were in for great entertainment, and you were probably in the middle of a very fun weekend.The Fourth Season of TFTC is as excellent as the previous one and set the stage for Season Five, which became the pinnacle of the series. There are a whole slew of sordid sagas for the benefit of fright-fiends, let's take a look at each one.*** POSSIBLE MILD SPOILERS ***1. "None But The Lonely Heart" - A Tom Hanks directed drama about a con-man who goes around marrying old ladies, then offing them and taking their cash. Treat Williams plays the con-man in question and is known for being a very capable slimeball on film. A legendary HBO Sports personality makes a surprise appearance at the end. This is a solid episode, not mindblowing, but it normally takes an episode or two for these sets to really get rolling. 3 and a half Stars.2. "This'll Kill Ya" - Dylan McDermott's an arrogant pharmacist who gets his coworkers so upset they decide to play a very cruel prank on him. Dark, surreal, with some disturbing sex scenes. Another solid installment, but nothing brilliant. 3 and a half Stars.3. "On A Deadman's Chest" - Excellent installment about a rock singer who has extreme tattoo regret. Like another famous rock star of the time, Wayne Campbell, he hooks up with Tia Carrere. But things don't go as well for him as they did for Wayne. 4 Stars.4. "Seance" - Awesome episode. The cast here is fabulous, Cathy Moriarty is a phoney fortune teller scamming the great John Vernon. Ben Cross plays her partner. Cross was Barnabas Collins in the under-rated Dark Shadows Revival series of 1990. This is a very eerie episode with a perfect ending. 4 and a half Stars.5. "Beauty Rest" - Here you go, the big stinker of the season. Every season has at least one real crappy episode and that's what you have here. Mimi Rogers and Kathy Ireland are roommates / competing models in this yawner. Mimi goes crazy with jealousy, and why wouldn't she, she's hideous compared to Kathy Ireland. Now, usually I never miss a Kathy Ireland project, most people know how great she was in Alien From L.A., but this episode is no Alien From L.A.. 1 and a half Stars.6. "What's Cookin'" - Classic installment with Superman, Christopher Reeve, as the proprietor of an all-squid diner. Luckily for him he meets Judd Nelson in his best role in years, and before you know it, the public is going squid-crazy and the squid-steaks are flying off the grill like squid-cakes. Meat Loaf is in this too, and not surprisingly, his corpse is eaten. Normally I don't give out spoilers, but most of the time when you see Meat Loaf on TV you know he is eventually going to be chopped up and eaten. Marvelous. 5 Stars.7. "The New Arrival" - Horrifically creepy episode about a radio psychiatrist who is no Frasier Crane when it comes to ratings. Frasier basically rules the airwaves in Seattle. But this doc, who doesn't have a fraction of Dr. Crane's talent or even-temper, has to resort to gimmicks like a remote broadcast from the home of a listener. You see, the doc specializes in child psychology and decides to visit the home of an extremely disturbed young girl. The results are quite unnerving. There are some geuinely scary parts. I think the ending could have gone in a better direction, but this is still one of my favorites. 5 Stars.8. "Showdown" - Here you have a surreal, rather slow-moving episode about an outlaw who visits a strangely familar Old West town. The lead is played by the guy who played Kramer's friend Brodie in an episode of Seinfeld. Brodie was another gunslinger, he pulled a gun on Jerry in a movie theatre after Jerry made fun of his giant bag of candy. This episode is not as good as that Seinfeld, which was remarkable... but it's still very good. 3 and a half Stars.9. "King of the Road" - Some early Brad Pitt here, he plays a crazy young street racer, obsessed with challenging the legendary old school racing king who has now become a cop. Just as some episodes are more "Two-Fisted Tales" than "Tales From The Crypt", this one is definitely more on the "Crime Suspenstories" side of things. This is an OK thriller, but you don't feel that it needed to be a TFTC episode. As always, however, there is the Cryptkeeper intro and outro, which can be depended upon to make any episode watchable. 3 Stars.10. "Maniac At Large" - Phenomenal installment. This is about a librarian consumed with paranoia of a serial killer stalking her neighborhood. The lead is played by Blythe Danner and she does a good job of portraying a demented librarian. There's a morbid atmosphere that I found very effective. Horror-Anthology vet Clarence Williams III (Tales From the Hood) appears in this, as well as Mr. Goody Two-Shoes, Adam Ant. I know what you're thinking, Adam Ant is the killer. Any sensible person would think that. But you have to watch it to see. 4 and a half Stars.11. "Split Personality" - A Joe Pesci black comedy about a con-man running a gimmick on a pair of rich twin girls. Now, back in the days when this episode came out, Joe Pesci was one of America's most treasured movie stars. He was the top guy based on his work with Scorsese, the Lethal Weapon movies, and My Cousin Vinny. Pesci could do no wrong. All until the great heel-turn of Gone Fishin', when we knew we'd never again see the goldenboy that stole our hearts in Goodfellas. And unfortunately, this episode has more in common with Gone Fishin' than Goodfellas. It's completely unbelievable, and ultimately, pretty stupid. Too bad, because Burt Young is also in this. You would think teaming Joe Pesci, Burt Young, and the Cryptkeeper up, you can't go wrong, right? Wrong. 2 and a half Stars.12. "Strung Along" - In the tradition of "The Ventriloquist's Dummy", this episode features, instead of an evil dummy, an evil marionette. Zach Galligan plays an apprentice puppeteer to an old master attempting a marionette comeback. The puppet is pretty evil, and let's face it, who doesn't love to see an evil puppet in action. The only problem for the puppet is that he has to deal wth Billy from Gremlins. A guy who has gone to battle with Stripe and hundreds of other evil gremlins. He's not exactly going to be fainting at the sight of a murderous clown marionette. Another super TFTC installment. 4 and a half Stars.13. "Werewolf Concerto" - This is my favorite episode of this set. Timothy Dalton plays a werewolf on vacation at a resort. One thing leads to another, and  the corpses start piling up. It becomes a supernatural murder mystery with a lot of skeptical vacationers facing the reality of werewolves and vampires in their midst. A unique take on the classic horror monsters that's scary and funny at the same time. Episodes like these are what I have always thought Tales From The Crypt should be about. In addition to the great James Bond actor, Timothy Dalton, you also have Dennis Farina, the hot Beverly DeAngelo, Roger Rabbit himself - Charles Fleischer, and Reginald VelJohnson, who was Carl Winslow on Family Matters. I wonder if Carl would rather have The Cryptkeeper living next door to him than Steve Urkel.  5 Stars.14. "Curiosity Killed" - A weird season finale about some elderly folks on a camping trip. Things are going great until they start drinking youth potions. Which is strange because you would assume drinking a youth potion could only lead to happiness. I blame Margot Kidder. 3 Stars.Tales From The Crypt in its prime. Everything up to Season Five is absolutely essential, I literally wear out DVD players with these DVDs. I have a massive DVD collection, but the ones I watch the most are The Simpsons, Batman The Animated Series, and Tales From The Crypt. This is my favorite stuff. For fans of horror anthology or of 90s TV. I give this my highest recommendation.

reviewText: The fourth season of Tales From the Crypt was another fantastically ghoulish season of horror vignettes based on the classic EC horror comics.  As before, season four features a bevy of talent in front of and behind the camera, beginning with the Tom Hanks directed "None But the Lonely Heart", which stars Treat Williams as a paranoid killer who fears that someone is out to get him.  The great William Friedkin directs "On a Dead Man's Chest" which stars Tia Carerre as a groupie who convinces her rocker love toy to get a tattoo, and at what a cost!  Stephen Hopkins offers up another entry in the series, with "Beauty Rest" which stars Mimi Rogers as an aging wanna-be model who goes to great lengths to secure herself a spot in a beauty pagent, and she gets much, much more than she bargained for.  David Warner stars as a radio child psychologist in the "The New Arrival", called in to a special case, and well, let's just say that this is no ordinary child.  Richard Donner and Frank Darabont team up for "Showdown", as a murderous cowboy learns a new definition for the word ghost town, and a young Brad Pitt makes a memorable appearance in "King of the Road", as a drag racer blackmailing a former racer turned cop into one last ride, at any price.  Season four features three classic episodes as well, including "What's Cooking" in which a drifter (Judd Nelson) changes the lives of husband and wife diner owners (Christopher Reeve, Bess Armstrong) by helping them put something new on the menu, the Joel Silver directed "Split Personality" which stars Joe Pesci as a con artist working a pair of twins, and the season closing "Curiousity Killed" which stars Margot Kidder as an elderly, nagging wife who believes her husband is trying to kill her, but learns something else even more startling instead.  All in all, season four of Tales From the Crypt is yet another excellent season of fun frights, and just like the previous volumes, this is a must own for fans of the series.

reviewText: Weird. After finally finding itself in Season Three, the series pretty much collapses in Season Four. Great casts (and sometimes directors) but consistently stale stories (how many times have we seen the sentient doll tale?) with few thrills. Only Split Personality, with Joe Pesci in full-bore Joe Pesci mode and a lavish gross-out ending, reprises the raw, ballsy spirit of the previous season.
summary: The bottom of the barrel (at the time)

reviewText: The Tales From the Crypt series was some of the best television airing back in the final year of the 80s and into the early 90s. Deliberately over the top. Deliberately funny. Deliberately campy at times. Deliberately scary. Deliberately gory. Deliberately one of HBO's finest creations.The episodes are all based on EC Comics of old...mostly from the self titled Tales From the Crypt, Haunt of Fear and Vault of Horror comic books. But I'd guess that 90% of you reading this already know that, and you're here as I am delighted that it is finally out on DVD.For those that have not seen these wonderfully entertaining episodes of dark humor and horror...if you're into the genre this collection and any of the other HBO seasonal Tales From the Crypt releases are for you.Season 4 includes:"None But the Lonely Heart" - Tom Hanks directed gold-digger meets grave-digger tale."This'll Kill Ya" - Time to take your medicine!"On A Deadman's Chest" - Tattoo you voodoo."Seance" - Fake psychics get real."Beauty Rest" - Jealousy will get you everywhere."What's Cookin'" - Oh no...not meatloaf for dinner again!"The New Arrival" - Psychologists should never make house calls."Showdown" - This place is a ghost town!"King of the Road" - 'Pitt' stop."Manic at Large" - Paranoid schizophrenic reverse serial killerism."Split Personality" - Joe Pesci stars...Funny? Funny how? Like a killer clown funny?"Strung Along" - Puppet really cuts loose!"Werewolf Concerto" - Open wide and say owwoooooooh!"Curiosity Killed" - I'd die to be young forever.Hit the buy button. These'll kill ya!

reviewText: Despite this having a few REALLY awful episodes, there are plenty more good ones that I very much enjoyed, it was an especially nice treat to see an episode from my childhood, Split Personality. I recommend this fourth season, it had plenty of great actors, really good episodes, and lots of ghoulicious fun my kiddies! My favorite episodes of this season are: What's Cookin', None but the Lonely Heart, and Split Personality.Tales from the Crypt: Season Four **** out of *****Violent Content: 6/10 - Strong Graphic Bloody Violence, Gore, Disturbing Frightening, and Gory Imagery,Sexuality/Nudity: 6/10 - Strong Sexuality, and Some Graphic Nudity.Star Rating, ZERO STARS - ***** Stars, Gore Rating, 0-10 --None but the Lonely Heart **** (1) - Brief Blood & Gruesome Imagery.-This'll Kill Ya *1/2 (1) - Brief Violence.-On a Deadman's Chest ***1/2 (4) - Some Strong Bloody Violence & Gory Imagery.-Seance ** (5) - A Gory Death and Some Bloody & Gory Imagery.-Beauty Rest **1/2 (1) - Some Violence and a Graphic Gory Imagery.-What's Cookin' **** (2) - Some Violence, Brief Gore, and Gory Imagery.-The New Arrival ***1/2 (1) - Some Violence.-Showdown ***1/2 (4) - Some Strong Bloody Western Violence.-King of the Road ** (1) - Some Violence and Car Wrecks.-Maniac at Large  *1/2 (2) - Some Violence and a Bloody Murder.-Split Personality **** (5) - A Strong, Gory Murder.-Strung Along *1/2 (0) - Brief Violence and Bloody Imagery.-Werewolf Concerto **1/2 (5) - Violence and Some Gore.-Curiosity Killed ZERO STARS (1) - Murders by Poisoning, and a Gory Aftermath.
summary: Yes! This is a much better improvement over season 3!
